title: Students leave flat trashed and full of joint ends, graffiti and knickers
text:

Shocking pictures show the gross state a group of university students left a flat in this summer after years of parties.

Graffiti is daubed on windows and doors, dirty underwear and lube wrappers are dumped on the floor and pub and road signs are strewn in the garden of the property in central Edinburgh, Scotland.

The disgusted landlord shared the images with Edinburgh Live today.

But he said the costs to repair and restore the property will not be covered by the deposit put down.

The man, who doesn't want to be named, said a local letting agency, which was managing the property, deemed everything to be fine at the last inspection.

(Image: dailyrecord.co.uk)

(Image: dailyrecord.co.uk)

Other pictures show messages written on a window appearing to show a tally of the amount of joints smoked.

Another series of drawings have been scrawled on the large French doors.

Council road signs and pub A-boards have also been left behind in the property.

(Image: dailyrecord.co.uk)

It comes after shocking pictures captured the horrific state of a student accommodation dubbed a "construction zone" earlier this year.

Crumbling walls, dirty showers blocked with raw sewage, mould on surfaces and shattered windows are pictured at Hub On Campus Tuscaloosa - home to almost 200 young people.

It had promised luxury student housing and amenities for University of Alabama students in Tuscaloosa, Alabama, when it opened last August.

Its website, which boasts pictures of a rooftop pool, courtyards and fitness centres, says the "luxury student housing fulfills your every need" with "airy rooms sporting custom furnishings".

(Image: dailyrecord.co.uk)

(Image: dailyrecord.co.uk)

But disgusted students, whose photos have been seen by Mirror Online, said the halls ware filthy - and have been since they moved in months ago.

"When I first arrived to my room, I was met with a lot of construction-related dust on the floors, minor holes in the walls, unset floor panels, water damage on my walls/roof in the bedroom and a vape pod stuck into a USB wall outlet," said AJ Spurr, a second-year journalism and political science student.

Dozens of students and their parents are srill participating in an ongoing lawsuit against the City of Tuscaloosa for issuing the permits for the accommodation and its management for false advertising and fraud.
description: Pictures taken inside the flat in central Edinburgh, Scotland, show the students had amassed an array of random items in four years
